item.title: Ron's Functions & Procedures #1 - Contains 7
item.dc:creator: @Ron Ron
item.description:
@Ron wrote:

[quote=“Weibs, post:14, topic:14350”]Hey ron, I just applied for SRL Member, and I was wondering, do they talk about procedures that are needed and things like that in the SRL Board? Or future updates?

I’m so excited, lol, I can’t wait to try my hand at making some functions, I love the challenge of scripting :)[/quote]
Yeah that’s why I do the scripting stuff. I love doing things that involve puzzles and equations, you know?

Speaking of fun, just added 2 new functions!

Shift(TheString : String, HTML : Boolean) - Which will act as if the shift button has been pressed and will convert all the info in TheString. This works like Uppercase() except this also changes numbers and extra chas such as 1234567890 ,./;’[]-=` into it’s Shift form.

ShiftB(TheString, Between1, Between2 : String, HTML : Boolean) - This works like ShiftB except you can specify what you want to capitalize/shiftize by setting up the betweens. Such as if your string was…

9138 <4rsdjklf> hsjklafha893493 <90928> 30

and you wanted only the char’s inbetween the <'s and >'s will be shiftified.

ShiftB(‘9138 <4rsdjklf> hsjklafha893493 <90928> 30’, ‘<’, ‘>’, false);

The ShiftB function was a real challenge! Feels good to finish it lol.

~Ron

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @Weibs Weibs
item.description:
@Weibs wrote:

[quote=“Ron, post:6, topic:14350”][quote author=Weibs link=topic=21443.msg243472#msg243472 date=1158310936]
Say you have a string named string1 with the value of ‘moo cow moo!’ and you want to replace the animal name. Then you would use Replace(string1, ‘cow’, animal); This would find the ‘cow’ part in string1 and replace it with the value of animal. Of course, you’d have to define the value of animal, first.
[/quote]
Obviously.

You have to define everything everywhere lol. It’s not going to somehow magically know that cow is an animal and it should replace it. Instead of putting in animal, put in ‘cow’ or define animal. :P[/quote]

Thats what I meant by define the value of animal. You put var animal: String; and then later put animal:=‘dog’; or something, but yeah, you explained it better.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @Aftermath.v2 Aftermath.v2
item.description:
@Aftermath.v2 wrote:

Ron:

Please explain it better aftermath, I don’t understand.

In SCAR, comments are placed either with // or {InsertRandomStuffHere}. You could mark the replaced term with a comment {}, and then you’d get a{}ab.And make the script not replace the string with a trailing {}, and when it reaches the end of the file, go through and replace the {} with emptyness.

item.title: Ron's Functions & Procedures #1 - Contains 7
item.dc:creator: @Aftermath.v2 Aftermath.v2
item.description:
@Aftermath.v2 wrote:

[quote=“Ron, post:8, topic:14350”][quote author=Janilabo link=topic=21443.msg244069#msg244069 date=1158353216]
WOAH. Nice one, Ron. Thanks for sharing this one. <3

Too bad that it isn’t doing multiple replacing, as it would make it perfect.
[/quote]
Working on a ReplaceAll function.

Until then you can use…

Function ReplaceAll(TheString, Replacee, Replacer : String) : String;
Begin
  While (Not(Pos(Replacee, TheString) = 0)) do
  begin
    TheString := Replace(TheString, Replacee, Replacer);
  end;
  Result := TheString;
End;

There is a small glitch in the ReplaceAll function inwhich if you put in replace ‘a’ with ‘ab’ then it will continue forever, because the string it replaces, also contains the letter its replacing, so then it goes on forever in an infinite loop. Feedback on that so we can fix. ;)[/quote]

I suggest replacing it with replacement{} and having it check for {} after the ‘replacee’ to verify if it’s been replaced, and then when it is not located anymore, rescan the file and prune the {}.

Read full topic

Function ReplaceAll(TheString, Replacee, Replacer : String) : String;

There is a small glitch in the ReplaceAll function inwhich if you put in replace ‘a’ with ‘ab’ then it will continue forever, because the string it replaces, also contains the letter its replacing, so then it goes on forever in an infinite loop. Feedback on that so we can fix.

@Ron wrote:

Weibs:

Say you have a string named string1 with the value of ‘moo cow moo!’ and you want to replace the animal name. Then you would use Replace(string1, ‘cow’, animal); This would find the ‘cow’ part in string1 and replace it with the value of animal. Of course, you’d have to define the value of animal, first.

Obviously.

You have to define everything everywhere lol. It’s not going to somehow magically know that cow is an animal and it should replace it. Instead of putting in animal, put in ‘cow’ or define animal.

[quote=“bullzeye95, post:4, topic:14350”]I don’t get it

What does it do? I read, but I’m stupid.[/quote]

The “Test this program” part of my topic, will show that it’s using the Replace function to replace the letters ‘abc’ with ‘32123’ in the string ‘abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz’.

WriteLn(Replace(‘abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz’, ‘abc’, ‘32123’));

So when you test out the script, it will result in:

32123defghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz

Understand? It replaced the letters abc with 32123.

item.title: Ron's Functions & Procedures #1 - Contains 7
item.dc:creator: @Ron Ron
item.description:
@Ron wrote:

[anchor=top][center][size=15pt]Ron’s Functions & Procedures #1[/size][/center]

All functions and procedures on this page.

[ul][] [iurl=#replace]Replace();[/iurl] - Replace this with that!
[] [iurl=#findallocc]FindAllOcc();[/iurl] - Returns the occurrences of a string inside another string.
[] [iurl=#explode]Explode();[/iurl] - Creates an array very easily using just 1 string.
[] [iurl=#shift]Shift();[/iurl] - Shiftizes a string.
[] [iurl=#shiftb]ShiftB();[/iurl] - Shiftizes between this and this.
[] [iurl=#createfile]CreateFile();[/iurl] - Quick way to create a file.
[*] [iurl=#minimizetotray]MinimizeToTray;[/iurl] - Minimizes SCAR to the tray.[/ul]

[anchor=replace][/anchor]
Function: Replace();
Syntax: Replace(TheString, Replacee, Replacer : String) : String;
What it does: Replaces the Replacee with the Replacer inside TheString.

Replace() function code only:

// The Replace() function will replace a string with another string.
// Made by Ron. :)
function Replace(TheString, Replacee, Replacer : String) : String;
var
  a : LongInt;
begin
  a := Pos(Replacee, TheString);
  if(a = 0)then
  begin
    // Do nothing...
  end else
  begin
    Delete(TheString, a, Length(Replacee));
    Insert(Replacer, TheString, a);
  end;
  Result := TheString;
end;

Test the Replace() function by using this program.

Program TestReplaceFunction;

// The Replace() function will replace a string with another string.
// Made by Ron. :)
function Replace(TheString, Replacee, Replacer : String) : String;
var
  a : LongInt;
begin
  a := Pos(Replacee, TheString);
  if(a = 0)then
  begin
    // Do nothing...
  end else
  begin
    Delete(TheString, a, Length(Replacee));
    Insert(Replacer, TheString, a);
  end;
  Result := TheString;
end;

Begin
  ClearDebug;
  WriteLn(Replace('abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz', 'abc', '32123'));
End.

[right][iurl=#top]Back to Top?[/iurl][/right]
[hr]
[anchor=findallocc][/anchor]
Function: FindAllOcc();
Syntax: FindAllOcc(LookFor, TheString : String) : Integer;
What it does: Finds all the occurrences of what you’re looking for in a string and returns how many times it was found.
Note: This function requires the Replace() function before it.

FindAllOcc() function code only.

// The FindAllOcc() function finds all the occurrences of something in a string.
// Made by Ron. :)
Function FindAllOcc(LookFor, TheString : String) : Integer;
Var
  a : Integer;
  b : LongInt;
  FunctStr : String;
Begin
  FunctStr := TheString;
  Repeat
    b := Pos(LookFor, FunctStr);
    If(Not(b = 0))Then
    Begin
      a := a + 1;
    End;
    FunctStr := Replace(FunctStr, LookFor, '');
  Until(b = 0)
  Result := a;
End;

Test the FindAllOcc() function by using this program.

Program TestFindAllOccFunction;

// The Replace() function will replace a string with another string.
// Made by Ron. :)
function Replace(TheString, Replacee, Replacer : String) : String;
var
  a : LongInt;
begin
  a := Pos(Replacee, TheString);
  if(a = 0)then
  begin
    // Do nothing...
  end else
  begin
    Delete(TheString, a, Length(Replacee));
    Insert(Replacer, TheString, a);
  end;
  Result := TheString;
end;

// The FindAllOcc() function finds all the occurrences of something in a string.
// Made by Ron. :)
Function FindAllOcc(LookFor, TheString : String) : Integer;
Var
  a : Integer;
  b : LongInt;
  FunctStr : String;
Begin
  FunctStr := TheString;
  Repeat
    b := Pos(LookFor, FunctStr);
    If(Not(b = 0))Then
    Begin
      a := a + 1;
    End;
    FunctStr := Replace(FunctStr, LookFor, '');
  Until(b = 0)
  Result := a;
End;

Begin
  ClearDebug;
  ChangeReportWidth(0);
  WriteLn(IntToStr(FindAllOcc('Moo', 'Moo Moo Moo')));
End.

[right][iurl=#top]Back to Top?[/iurl][/right]
[hr]
[anchor=explode][/anchor]
Function: Explode();
Syntax: Explode(Separator, TheString : String): Array of String;
What it does: Looks through a string and separates it with whatever you supplied as a separator, and takes each value and puts them into an array.
Note: This function requires the Replace() and FindAllOcc() function before it.

Explode() function code only:

// The Explode procedure looks through a string and separates it with whatever
// you suplied as a separator, and takes each value and puts them into an array.
// Example: Explode('*', 'a*b*c*d*e*');
// Made by Ron. Fixed by Weibs. :)
function Explode(Separator, TheString : String) : Array of String;
var
  ArrayName : Array of String;
  FunctStr, c : String;
  a, i : Integer;
begin
  FunctStr := TheString;
  a := FindAllOcc(Separator, FunctStr);
  SetArrayLength(ArrayName, a+1);
  for i := 0 to a do
  begin
    if(i = a)then
    begin
      ArrayName[i] := FunctStr;
    end else
    begin
      c := Copy(FunctStr, 1, Pos(Separator, FunctStr)-1);
      ArrayName[i] := c;
      FunctStr := Replace(FunctStr, c+Separator, '');
    end;
  end;
  Result := ArrayName;
end;

Test the Explode() function by using this program.

Program Test_Explode_Function;

Const
  // Separate each value with what?
  Separator = ' ';
  // Split each one with whatever the Separator is.
  TheArray = 'just1 no2 maybe3 or4 howabout5 noway6 iwant7 iwant8 iwant9';

var
  MyArray : Array of String;
  a : Integer;

// The Replace() function will replace a string with another string.
// Made by Ron. :)
function Replace(TheString, Replacee, Replacer : String) : String;
var
  a : LongInt;
begin
  a := Pos(Replacee, TheString);
  if(a = 0)then
  begin
    // Do nothing...
  end else
  begin
    Delete(TheString, a, Length(Replacee));
    Insert(Replacer, TheString, a);
  end;
  Result := TheString;
end;

// The FindAllOcc() function finds all the occurrences of something in a string.
// Made by Ron. :)
function FindAllOcc(LookFor, TheString : String) : Integer;
var
  a : Integer;
  b : LongInt;
  FunctStr : String;
begin
  FunctStr := TheString;
  Repeat
    b := Pos(LookFor, FunctStr);
    if(Not(b = 0))then
    begin
      a := a + 1;
    end;
    FunctStr := Replace(FunctStr, LookFor, '');
  Until(b = 0)
  Result := a;
end;

// The Explode procedure looks through a string and separates it with whatever
// you suplied as a separator, and takes each value and puts them into an array.
// Example: Explode('*', 'a*b*c*d*e*');
// Made by Ron. Fixed by Weibs. :)
function Explode(Separator, TheString : String) : Array of String;
var
  ArrayName : Array of String;
  FunctStr, c : String;
  a, i : Integer;
begin
  FunctStr := TheString;
  a := FindAllOcc(Separator, FunctStr);
  SetArrayLength(ArrayName, a+1);
  for i := 0 to a do
  begin
    if(i = a)then
    begin
      ArrayName[i] := FunctStr;
    end else
    begin
      c := Copy(FunctStr, 1, Pos(Separator, FunctStr)-1);
      ArrayName[i] := c;
      FunctStr := Replace(FunctStr, c+Separator, '');
    end;
  end;
  Result := ArrayName;
end;

begin
  ClearDebug;
  ChangeReportWidth(0);
  MyArray := Explode(Separator, TheArray);
  for a := 0 to 8 do
  begin
    WriteLn('  MyArray['+IntToStr(a)+'] := ''' + MyArray[a] + ''';');
  end;
end.

[right][iurl=#top]Back to Top?[/iurl][/right]
[hr]
[anchor=shift][/anchor]
Function: Shift();
Syntax: Shift(TheString : String; HTML : Boolean) : String;
What it does: It basically acts as a shift button and converts numbers, letters, and chars to its Shift form.
Note: This function requires the Replace() function before it.

Shift() function code only:

// The Shift() function will type in TheString as if shift was down.
// Made by Ron. :)
Function Shift(TheString : String; HTML : Boolean) : String;
Var
  i, c : Integer;
  Shifts, ShiftsA, Betw : String;
Begin
  Shifts  := '1234567890`-=[]\;''/,.';
  ShiftsA := '!@#$%^&*()~_+{}|:"?<>';
  For c := 1 to Length(TheString) do
  Begin
    For i := 1 to Length(Shifts) do
    Begin
      If(StrGet(TheString, c) = StrGet(Shifts, i))Then
      Begin
        TheString := Replace(TheString, StrGet(Shifts, i), StrGet(ShiftsA, i));
      End;
    End;
  End;
  TheString := Uppercase(TheString);
  If(HTML)Then
  Begin
    TheString := Replace(TheString, '<', '<');
    TheString := Replace(TheString, '>', '>');
  End;
  Result := TheString;
End;

Test the Shift() function by using this program.

Program TestShiftFunction;

Var
  TheString : String;

// The Replace() function will replace a string with another string.
// Made by Ron. :)
Function Replace(TheString, Replacee, Replacer : String) : String;
Var
  a : LongInt;
Begin
  a := Pos(Replacee, TheString);
  If(a = 0)Then
  Begin
    // Do nothing...
  End Else
  Begin
    Delete(TheString, a, Length(Replacee));
    Insert(Replacer, TheString, a);
    Result := TheString;
  End;
End;

// The Shift() function will type in TheString as if shift was down.
// Made by Ron. :)
Function Shift(TheString : String; HTML : Boolean) : String;
Var
  i, c : Integer;
  Shifts, ShiftsA, Betw : String;
Begin
  Shifts  := '1234567890`-=[]\;''/,.';
  ShiftsA := '!@#$%^&*()~_+{}|:"?<>';
  For c := 1 to Length(TheString) do
  Begin
    For i := 1 to Length(Shifts) do
    Begin
      If(StrGet(TheString, c) = StrGet(Shifts, i))Then
      Begin
        TheString := Replace(TheString, StrGet(Shifts, i), StrGet(ShiftsA, i));
      End;
    End;
  End;
  TheString := Uppercase(TheString);
  If(HTML)Then
  Begin
    TheString := Replace(TheString, '<', '<');
    TheString := Replace(TheString, '>', '>');
  End;
  Result := TheString;
End;

Begin
  ClearDebug;
  ChangeReportWidth(0);
  TheString := 'ABCDEF <12345> GHIJK `[];'',./';
  WriteLn('Shift(TheString : String; HTML : Boolean) - HTML set to false');
  WriteLn('  Original: ' + TheString);
  WriteLn('  After:    ' + Shift(TheString, False));
  WriteLn('Shift(TheString : String; HTML : Boolean) - HTML set to true');
  WriteLn('  Original: ' + TheString);
  WriteLn('  After:    ' + Shift(TheString, True));
End.

[right][iurl=#top]Back to Top?[/iurl][/right]
[hr]
[anchor=shiftb][/anchor]
Function: ShiftB();
Syntax: ShiftB(TheString, Between1, Between2 : String; HTML : Boolean) : String;
What it does: Acts just like Shift() except you can set what to convert to the shift form by setting up Between1 and Between2.
Note: This function requires the Replace() function before it if you are going to use it.

ShiftB() function code only:

// The ShiftB() function will type in between Between1 and Between2
// as if shift was down. Made by Ron. :)
Function ShiftB(TheString, Between1, Between2 : String; HTML : Boolean) : String;
Var
  i, c : Integer;
  Shifts, ShiftsA, Betw : String;
  Pos1 : LongInt;
Begin
  Shifts  := '1234567890`-=[]\;''/,.';
  ShiftsA := '!@#$%^&*()~_+{}|:"?<>';
  Betw := Uppercase(Between(Between1, Between2, TheString));
  Pos1 := Pos(Between1, TheString);
  Delete(TheString, Pos1+Length(Between1), Length(Betw));
  For c := 1 to Length(Betw) do
  Begin
    For i := 1 to Length(Shifts) do
    Begin
      If(StrGet(Betw, c) = StrGet(Shifts, i))Then
      Begin
        Betw := Replace(Betw, StrGet(Shifts, i), StrGet(ShiftsA, i));
      End;
    End;
  End;
  If(HTML)Then
  Begin
    Betw := Replace(Betw, '<', '<');
    Betw := Replace(Betw, '>', '>');
  End;
  Insert(Betw, TheString, Pos1+Length(Between1));
  Result := TheString;
End;

Test the ShiftB() function by using this program.

Program TestShiftBFunction;

Var
  TheString : String;

// The Replace() function will replace a string with another string.
// Made by Ron. :)
Function Replace(TheString, Replacee, Replacer : String) : String;
Var
  a : LongInt;
Begin
  a := Pos(Replacee, TheString);
  If(a = 0)Then
  Begin
    // Do nothing...
  End Else
  Begin
    Delete(TheString, a, Length(Replacee));
    Insert(Replacer, TheString, a);
    Result := TheString;
  End;
End;

// The ShiftB() function will type in between Between1 and Between2
// as if shift was down. Made by Ron. :)
Function ShiftB(TheString, Between1, Between2 : String; HTML : Boolean) : String;
Var
  i, c : Integer;
  Shifts, ShiftsA, Betw : String;
  Pos1 : LongInt;
Begin
  Shifts  := '1234567890`-=[]\;''/,.';
  ShiftsA := '!@#$%^&*()~_+{}|:"?<>';
  Betw := Uppercase(Between(Between1, Between2, TheString));
  Pos1 := Pos(Between1, TheString);
  Delete(TheString, Pos1+Length(Between1), Length(Betw));
  For c := 1 to Length(Betw) do
  Begin
    For i := 1 to Length(Shifts) do
    Begin
      If(StrGet(Betw, c) = StrGet(Shifts, i))Then
      Begin
        Betw := Replace(Betw, StrGet(Shifts, i), StrGet(ShiftsA, i));
      End;
    End;
  End;
  If(HTML)Then
  Begin
    Betw := Replace(Betw, '<', '<');
    Betw := Replace(Betw, '>', '>');
  End;
  Insert(Betw, TheString, Pos1+Length(Between1));
  Result := TheString;
End;

Begin
  ClearDebug;
  ChangeReportWidth(0);
  TheString := 'ABCDEF <12345> GHIJK `[];'',./';
  WriteLn('ShiftB(TheString, Between1, Between2 : String; HTML : Boolean) - HTML set to false');
  WriteLn('  Original: ' + TheString);
  WriteLn('  After:    ' + ShiftB(TheString, 'DEF', 'GHI', False));
  WriteLn('ShiftB(TheString, Between1, Between2 : String; HTML : Boolean) - HTML set to true');
  WriteLn('  Original: ' + TheString);
  WriteLn('  After:    ' + ShiftB(TheString, 'DEF', 'GHI', True));
End.

[anchor=createfile][/anchor]
Procedure: CreateFile();
Syntax: CreateFile(Information, Location, Title : String);
What it does: Creates a file by putting in the Information into the Location of the file, and labels it with the Title.

CreateFile() function code only:

// CreateFile will put in the information into the location of the file
// and label it with the Title. Made by Ron. :)
Procedure CreateFile(Information, Location, Title : String);
Var
  OutFile : Integer;
Begin
  OutFile := ReWriteFile(Location, False);
  // Check to see if the file was permitted.
  If(OutFile < 0)Then
  Begin
    // File not permitted, terminating.
    TerminateScript;
  End;
  WriteFileString(OutFile, Information);
  CloseFile(OutFile);
  WriteLn('Saved the file "' + Title + '" to:');
  WriteLn('  ' + Location);
End;

Test the CreateFile() function by using this program.

Program TestCreateFileProcedure;

// CreateFile will put in the information into the location of the file
// and label it with the Title. Made by Ron. :)
Procedure CreateFile(Information, Location, Title : String);
Var
  OutFile : Integer;
Begin
  OutFile := ReWriteFile(Location, False);
  // Check to see if the file was permitted.
  If(OutFile < 0)Then
  Begin
    // File not permitted, terminating.
    TerminateScript;
  End;
  WriteFileString(OutFile, Information);
  CloseFile(OutFile);
  WriteLn('Saved the file "' + Title + '" to:');
  WriteLn('  ' + Location);
End;

Begin
  ClearDebug;
  CreateFile('ABCDEF 12345', 'c:\CREATED_FILE\blah.txt', 'Blah.txt');
End.

[anchor=minimizetotray][/anchor]
Procedure: MinimizeToTray;
Syntax: MinimizeToTray;
What it does: It minimizes Scar by pressing Ctrl+M.

MinimizeToTray procedure code only:

// The Minimize Procedure will Minimize Scar by pressing Ctrl+M.
// Made by Ron. :)
Procedure MinimizeToTray;
Begin
  KeyDown(17);
  KeyDown(GetKeyCode('m'));
  KeyUp(GetKeyCode('m'));
  KeyUp(17);
End;

Test the MinimizeToTray; by using this program.

Program TestMinimizeToTrayProcedure;

// The Minimize Procedure will Minimize Scar by pressing Ctrl+M.
// Made by Ron. :)
Procedure MinimizeToTray;
Begin
  KeyDown(17);
  KeyDown(GetKeyCode('m'));
  KeyUp(GetKeyCode('m'));
  KeyUp(17);
End;

Begin
  ClearDebug;
  MinimizeToTray;
End.
